001package com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.oklab;
002
003import com.badlogic.gdx.graphics.Color;
004import com.badlogic.gdx.math.MathUtils;
005import com.badlogic.gdx.utils.NumberUtils;
006import com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.FloatColors;
007import com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.Shaders;
008import com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.ycwcm.Palette;
009
010import java.util.Random;
011
012/**
013 * Contains code for manipulating colors as {@code int} and packed {@code float} values in the Oklab color space.
014 * Oklab is a very new color space that builds on the same foundation as IPT, but seems to be better-calibrated for
015 * uniform lightness and colorfulness, instead of just the emphasis on uniform hue that IPT has.
016 * Here's <a href="https://bottosson.github.io/posts/oklab/">Ottosson's original post introducing Oklab</a>.
017 * So far, <a href="https://raphlinus.github.io/color/2021/01/18/oklab-critique.html">it stood up to analysis by Raph
018 * Levien</a>, and seems to be gaining fans quickly.
019 */
020public class ColorTools {
021        /**
022         * Gets a packed float representation of a color given as 4 float components, here, L (luminance or lightness), A
023         * (a chromatic component ranging from greenish to reddish, called protan in IPT), B (a chromatic component ranging
024         * from bluish to yellowish, called tritan in IPT), and alpha (or opacity). As long as you use a batch with
025         * {@link Shaders#fragmentShaderOklab} as its shader, colors passed with
026         * {@link com.badlogic.gdx.graphics.g2d.Batch#setPackedColor(float)} will be interpreted as Oklab. L should be
027         * between 0 and 1, inclusive, with 0 used for very dark colors (almost only black), and 1 used for very light
028         * colors (almost only white). A and B range from 0.0 to 1.0, with grayscale results when both are about 0.5.
029         * There's some aesthetic value in changing just one chroma value. When A is high and B is low, the color is more
030         * purple/magenta, when both are low it is more bluish, when B is high and A is low, the color tends to be greenish,
031         * and when both are high it tends to be orange. When A and B are both near 0.5f, the color is closer to gray.
032         * Alpha is the multiplicative opacity of the color, and acts like RGBA's alpha.
033         * <br>
034         * This method bit-masks the resulting color's byte values, so any values can technically be given to this as
035         * L, A, and B, but they will only be reversible from the returned float color to the original L,
036         * A, and B values if the original values were in the range that {@link #channelL(float)}, {@link #channelA(float)},
037         * and {@link #channelB(float)} return. You can use {@link #inGamut(float, float, float)} to check if a given set of
038         * L, A, and B values is in-gamut, that is, it can be converted to and from an RGB color without going out of the
039         * valid range. If you just want to enforce that a color is in-gamut, you can use
040         * {@link #limitToGamut(float, float, float, float)}, which takes the same parameters this method does, or
041         * {@link #limitToGamut(float)} if you already have a packed float color that could be out-of-gamut.
042         *
043         * @param l     0f to 1f, lightness or L component of Oklab, with 0.5f meaning "no change" and 1f brightening
044         * @param a     0f to 1f, protan or A component of Oklab, with 1f more orange, red, or magenta
045         * @param b     0f to 1f, tritan or B component of Oklab, with 1f more green, yellow, or red
046         * @param alpha 0f to 1f, 0f makes the color transparent and 1f makes it opaque
047         * @return a float encoding a color with the given properties
048         */
049        public static float oklab(float l, float a, float b, float alpha) {
050                return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(((int) (alpha * 255) << 24 & 0xFE000000) | ((int) (b * 255) << 16 & 0xFF0000)
051                                | ((int) (a * 255) << 8 & 0xFF00) | ((int) (l * 255) & 0xFF));
052        }
053
054
055        /**
056         * An approximation of the cube-root function for float inputs and outputs.
057         * This can be about twice as fast as {@link Math#cbrt(double)}. It
058         * correctly returns negative results when given negative inputs.
059         * <br>
060         * Has very low relative error (less than 1E-9) when inputs are uniformly
061         * distributed between -512 and 512, and absolute mean error of less than
062         * 1E-6 in the same scenario. Uses a bit-twiddling method similar to one
063         * presented in Hacker's Delight and also used in early 3D graphics (see
064         * https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fast_inverse_square_root for more, but
065         * this code approximates cbrt(x) and not 1/sqrt(x)). This specific code
066         * was originally by Marc B. Reynolds, posted in his "Stand-alone-junk"
067         * repo: https://github.com/Marc-B-Reynolds/Stand-alone-junk/blob/master/src/Posts/ballcube.c#L182-L197 .
068         * <br>
069         * This is used when converting from RGB to Oklab, as an intermediate step.
070         * @param x any finite float to find the cube root of
071         * @return the cube root of x, approximated
072         */
073        private static float cbrt(float x) {
074                int ix = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(x);
075                final int sign = ix & 0x80000000;
076                ix &= 0x7FFFFFFF;
077                final float x0 = x;
078                ix = (ix>>>2) + (ix>>>4);
079                ix += (ix>>>4);
080                ix = ix + (ix>>>8) + 0x2A5137A0 | sign;
081                x  = NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(ix);
082                x  = 0.33333334f*(2f * x + x0/(x*x));
083                x  = 0.33333334f*(2f * x + x0/(x*x));
084                return x;
085        }
086
087        /**
088         * Used when converting from Oklab to RGB, as an intermediate step.
089         * Really just {@code x * x * x}.
090         * @param x one of the LMS Prime channels to be converted to LMS
091         * @return an LMS channel value, which can be converted to RGB
092         */
093        private static float cube(final float x) {
094                return x * x * x;
095        }
096
097        /**
098         * Used when given non-linear sRGB inputs to make them linear, approximating with gamma 2.0.
099         * @param component any non-linear channel of a color, to be made linear
100         * @return a linear version of component
101         */
102        private static float forwardGamma(final float component) {
103                return component * component;
104        }
105
106        /**
107         * Used to return from a linear, gamma-corrected input to an sRGB, non-linear output, using gamma 2.0.
108         * @param component a linear channel of a color, to be made non-linear
109         * @return a non-linear version of component
110         */
111        private static float reverseGamma(final float component) {
112                return (float)Math.sqrt(component);
113        }
114
115
116        /**
117         * Converts a packed float color in the format produced by {@link ColorTools#oklab(float, float, float, float)} to an RGBA8888 int.
118         * This format of int can be used with Pixmap and in some other places in libGDX.
119         * @param packed a packed float color, as produced by {@link ColorTools#oklab(float, float, float, float)}
120         * @return an RGBA8888 int color
121         */
122        public static int toRGBA8888(final float packed)
123        {
124                final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(packed);
125                final float L = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
126                final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
127                final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
128                final float l = cube(L + 0.3963377774f * A + 0.2158037573f * B);
129                final float m = cube(L - 0.1055613458f * A - 0.0638541728f * B);
130                final float s = cube(L - 0.0894841775f * A - 1.2914855480f * B);
131                final int r = (int)(reverseGamma(MathUtils.clamp(+4.0767245293f * l - 3.3072168827f * m + 0.2307590544f * s, 0f, 1f)) * 255.999f);
132                final int g = (int)(reverseGamma(MathUtils.clamp(-1.2681437731f * l + 2.6093323231f * m - 0.3411344290f * s, 0f, 1f)) * 255.999f);
133                final int b = (int)(reverseGamma(MathUtils.clamp(-0.0041119885f * l - 0.7034763098f * m + 1.7068625689f * s, 0f, 1f)) * 255.999f);
134                return r << 24 | g << 16 | b << 8 | (decoded & 0xfe000000) >>> 24 | decoded >>> 31;
135        }
136
137        /**
138         * Converts a packed float color in the format produced by {@link ColorTools#oklab(float, float, float, float)}
139         * to a packed float in RGBA format.
140         * This format of float can be used with the standard SpriteBatch and in some other places in libGDX.
141         * @param packed a packed float color, as produced by {@link ColorTools#oklab(float, float, float, float)}
142         * @return a packed float color as RGBA
143         */
144        public static float toRGBA(final float packed)
145        {
146                final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(packed);
147                final float L = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
148                final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
149                final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
150                final float l = cube(L + 0.3963377774f * A + 0.2158037573f * B);
151                final float m = cube(L - 0.1055613458f * A - 0.0638541728f * B);
152                final float s = cube(L - 0.0894841775f * A - 1.2914855480f * B);
153                final int r = (int)(reverseGamma(MathUtils.clamp(+4.0767245293f * l - 3.3072168827f * m + 0.2307590544f * s, 0f, 1f)) * 255.999f);
154                final int g = (int)(reverseGamma(MathUtils.clamp(-1.2681437731f * l + 2.6093323231f * m - 0.3411344290f * s, 0f, 1f)) * 255.999f);
155                final int b = (int)(reverseGamma(MathUtils.clamp(-0.0041119885f * l - 0.7034763098f * m + 1.7068625689f * s, 0f, 1f)) * 255.999f);
156                return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(r | g << 8 | b << 16 | (decoded & 0xfe000000));
157        }
158        /**
159         * Writes an Oklab-format packed float color (the format produced by {@link ColorTools#oklab(float, float, float, float)})
160         * into an RGBA8888 Color as used by libGDX (called {@code editing}).
161         * @param editing a libGDX color that will be filled in-place with an RGBA conversion of {@code packed}
162         * @param packed a packed float color, as produced by {@link ColorTools#oklab(float, float, float, float)}
163         * @return an RGBA8888 int color
164         */
165        public static Color toColor(Color editing, final float packed)
166        {
167                final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(packed);
168                final float L = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
169                final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
170                final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
171                final float l = cube(L + 0.3963377774f * A + 0.2158037573f * B);
172                final float m = cube(L - 0.1055613458f * A - 0.0638541728f * B);
173                final float s = cube(L - 0.0894841775f * A - 1.2914855480f * B);
174                editing.r = reverseGamma(MathUtils.clamp(+4.0767245293f * l - 3.3072168827f * m + 0.2307590544f * s, 0f, 1f));
175                editing.g = reverseGamma(MathUtils.clamp(-1.2681437731f * l + 2.6093323231f * m - 0.3411344290f * s, 0f, 1f));
176                editing.b = reverseGamma(MathUtils.clamp(-0.0041119885f * l - 0.7034763098f * m + 1.7068625689f * s, 0f, 1f));
177                editing.a = (decoded >>> 25) * 0x1.020408p-7f; // this is 1/127 as a float
178                return editing.clamp();
179        }
180
181        /**
182         * Takes a color encoded as an RGBA8888 int and converts to a packed float in the Oklab format this uses.
183         * @param rgba an int with the channels (in order) red, green, blue, alpha; should have 8 bits per channel
184         * @return a packed float as Oklab, which this class can use
185         */
186        public static float fromRGBA8888(final int rgba) {
187                final float r = forwardGamma((rgba >>> 24) * 0x1.010101010101p-8f);
188                final float g = forwardGamma((rgba >>> 16 & 0xFF) * 0x1.010101010101p-8f);
189                final float b = forwardGamma((rgba >>> 8 & 0xFF) * 0x1.010101010101p-8f);
190
191                final float l = cbrt(0.4121656120f * r + 0.5362752080f * g + 0.0514575653f * b);
192                final float m = cbrt(0.2118591070f * r + 0.6807189584f * g + 0.1074065790f * b);
193                final float s = cbrt(0.0883097947f * r + 0.2818474174f * g + 0.6302613616f * b);
194
195                return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(
196                                      MathUtils.clamp((int)((0.2104542553f * l + 0.7936177850f * m - 0.0040720468f * s       ) * 255.999f), 0, 255)
197                                                | MathUtils.clamp((int)((0.9889992500f * l - 1.2142961000f * m + 0.2252968500f * s + 0.5f) * 255.999f), 0, 255) << 8
198                                                | MathUtils.clamp((int)((0.0129520185f * l + 0.3913858800f * m - 0.4043378800f * s + 0.5f) * 255.999f), 0, 255) << 16
199                                                | (rgba & 0xFE) << 24);
200        }
201
202        /**
203         * Takes a color encoded as an RGBA8888 packed float and converts to a packed float in the Oklab format this uses.
204         * @param packed a packed float in RGBA8888 format, with A in the MSB and R in the LSB
205         * @return a packed float as Oklab, which this class can use
206         */
207        public static float fromRGBA(final float packed) {
208                final int abgr = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(packed);
209                final float r = forwardGamma((abgr & 0xFF) * 0x1.010101010101p-8f);
210                final float g = forwardGamma((abgr >>> 8 & 0xFF) * 0x1.010101010101p-8f);
211                final float b = forwardGamma((abgr >>> 16 & 0xFF) * 0x1.010101010101p-8f);
212                final float l = cbrt(0.4121656120f * r + 0.5362752080f * g + 0.0514575653f * b);
213                final float m = cbrt(0.2118591070f * r + 0.6807189584f * g + 0.1074065790f * b);
214                final float s = cbrt(0.0883097947f * r + 0.2818474174f * g + 0.6302613616f * b);
215                return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(
216                                          MathUtils.clamp((int)((0.2104542553f * l + 0.7936177850f * m - 0.0040720468f * s       ) * 255.999f), 0, 255)
217                                                | MathUtils.clamp((int)((0.9889992500f * l - 1.2142961000f * m + 0.2252968500f * s + 0.5f) * 255.999f), 0, 255) << 8
218                                                | MathUtils.clamp((int)((0.0129520185f * l + 0.3913858800f * m - 0.4043378800f * s + 0.5f) * 255.999f), 0, 255) << 16
219                                                | (abgr & 0xFE000000));
220        }
221
222        // original multipliers for LMS when obtaining the non-shrunken A and B values:
223        //+0.2104542553 +0.7936177850 -0.0040720468
224        //+1.9779984951 -2.4285922050 +0.4505937099
225        //+0.0259040371 +0.7827717662 -0.8086757660
226
227        /**
228         * Takes a libGDX Color that uses RGBA8888 channels and converts to a packed float in the Oklab format this uses.
229         * @param color a libGDX RGBA8888 Color
230         * @return a packed float as Oklab, which this class can use
231         */
232        public static float fromColor(final Color color) {
233                final float r = forwardGamma(color.r);
234                final float g = forwardGamma(color.g);
235                final float b = forwardGamma(color.b);
236                final float l = cbrt(0.4121656120f * r + 0.5362752080f * g + 0.0514575653f * b);
237                final float m = cbrt(0.2118591070f * r + 0.6807189584f * g + 0.1074065790f * b);
238                final float s = cbrt(0.0883097947f * r + 0.2818474174f * g + 0.6302613616f * b);
239                return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(
240                                          MathUtils.clamp((int)((0.2104542553f * l + 0.7936177850f * m - 0.0040720468f * s       ) * 255.999f), 0, 255)
241                                                | MathUtils.clamp((int)((0.9889992500f * l - 1.2142961000f * m + 0.2252968500f * s + 0.5f) * 255.999f), 0, 255) << 8
242                                                | MathUtils.clamp((int)((0.0129520185f * l + 0.3913858800f * m - 0.4043378800f * s + 0.5f) * 255.999f), 0, 255) << 16
243                                                | ((int)(color.a * 255f) << 24 & 0xFE000000));
244        }
245
246        /**
247         * Takes RGBA components from 0.0 to 1.0 each and converts to a packed float in the Oklab format this uses.
248         * @param r red, from 0.0 to 1.0 (both inclusive)
249         * @param g green, from 0.0 to 1.0 (both inclusive)
250         * @param b blue, from 0.0 to 1.0 (both inclusive)
251         * @param a alpha, from 0.0 to 1.0 (both inclusive)
252         * @return a packed float as Oklab, which this class can use
253         */
254        public static float fromRGBA(float r, float g, float b, final float a) {
255                r = forwardGamma(r);
256                g = forwardGamma(g);
257                b = forwardGamma(b);
258                final float l = cbrt(0.4121656120f * r + 0.5362752080f * g + 0.0514575653f * b);
259                final float m = cbrt(0.2118591070f * r + 0.6807189584f * g + 0.1074065790f * b);
260                final float s = cbrt(0.0883097947f * r + 0.2818474174f * g + 0.6302613616f * b);
261                return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(
262                                          MathUtils.clamp((int)((0.2104542553f * l + 0.7936177850f * m - 0.0040720468f * s       ) * 255.999f), 0, 255)
263                                                | MathUtils.clamp((int)((0.9889992500f * l - 1.2142961000f * m + 0.2252968500f * s + 0.5f) * 255.999f), 0, 255) << 8
264                                                | MathUtils.clamp((int)((0.0129520185f * l + 0.3913858800f * m - 0.4043378800f * s + 0.5f) * 255.999f), 0, 255) << 16
265                                                | ((int)(a * 255f) << 24 & 0xFE000000));
266        }
267
268        /**
269         * Gets the red channel value of the given encoded color, as an int ranging from 0 to 255, inclusive.
270         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}
271         * @return an int from 0 to 255, inclusive, representing the red channel value of the given encoded color
272         */
273        public static int redInt(final float encoded)
274        {
275                final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
276                final float L = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
277                final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
278                final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
279                final float l = cube(L + 0.3963377774f * A + 0.2158037573f * B);
280                final float m = cube(L - 0.1055613458f * A - 0.0638541728f * B);
281                final float s = cube(L - 0.0894841775f * A - 1.2914855480f * B);
282                return (int)(reverseGamma(MathUtils.clamp(+4.0767245293f * l - 3.3072168827f * m + 0.2307590544f * s, 0f, 1f)) * 255.999f);
283        }
284
285        /**
286         * Gets the green channel value of the given encoded color, as an int ranging from 0 to 255, inclusive.
287         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}
288         * @return an int from 0 to 255, inclusive, representing the green channel value of the given encoded color
289         */
290        public static int greenInt(final float encoded)
291        {
292                final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
293                final float L = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
294                final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
295                final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
296                final float l = cube(L + 0.3963377774f * A + 0.2158037573f * B);
297                final float m = cube(L - 0.1055613458f * A - 0.0638541728f * B);
298                final float s = cube(L - 0.0894841775f * A - 1.2914855480f * B);
299                return (int)(reverseGamma(MathUtils.clamp(-1.2681437731f * l + 2.6093323231f * m - 0.3411344290f * s, 0f, 1f)) * 255.999f);
300        }
301
302        /**
303         * Gets the blue channel value of the given encoded color, as an int ranging from 0 to 255, inclusive.
304         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}
305         * @return an int from 0 to 255, inclusive, representing the blue channel value of the given encoded color
306         */
307        public static int blueInt(final float encoded)
308        {
309                final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
310                final float L = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
311                final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
312                final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
313                final float l = cube(L + 0.3963377774f * A + 0.2158037573f * B);
314                final float m = cube(L - 0.1055613458f * A - 0.0638541728f * B);
315                final float s = cube(L - 0.0894841775f * A - 1.2914855480f * B);
316                return (int)(reverseGamma(MathUtils.clamp(-0.0041119885f * l - 0.7034763098f * m + 1.7068625689f * s, 0f, 1f)) * 255.999f);
317        }
318
319        /**
320         * Gets the alpha channel value of the given encoded color, as an even int ranging from 0 to 254, inclusive. Because
321         * of how alpha is stored in libGDX, no odd-number values are possible for alpha.
322         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}
323         * @return an even int from 0 to 254, inclusive, representing the alpha channel value of the given encoded color
324         */
325        public static int alphaInt(final float encoded)
326        {
327                return (NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encoded) & 0xfe000000) >>> 24;
328        }
329
330        /**
331         * Gets the red channel value of the given encoded color, as a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive.
332         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}
333         * @return a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive, representing the red channel value of the given encoded color
334         */
335        public static float red(final float encoded)
336        {
337                final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
338                final float L = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
339                final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
340                final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
341                final float l = cube(L + 0.3963377774f * A + 0.2158037573f * B);
342                final float m = cube(L - 0.1055613458f * A - 0.0638541728f * B);
343                final float s = cube(L - 0.0894841775f * A - 1.2914855480f * B);
344                return reverseGamma(MathUtils.clamp(+4.0767245293f * l - 3.3072168827f * m + 0.2307590544f * s, 0f, 1f));
345        }
346
347        /**
348         * Gets the green channel value of the given encoded color, as a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive.
349         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}
350         * @return a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive, representing the green channel value of the given encoded color
351         */
352        public static float green(final float encoded)
353        {
354                final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
355                final float L = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
356                final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
357                final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
358                final float l = cube(L + 0.3963377774f * A + 0.2158037573f * B);
359                final float m = cube(L - 0.1055613458f * A - 0.0638541728f * B);
360                final float s = cube(L - 0.0894841775f * A - 1.2914855480f * B);
361                return reverseGamma(MathUtils.clamp(-1.2681437731f * l + 2.6093323231f * m - 0.3411344290f * s, 0f, 1f));
362        }
363
364        /**
365         * Gets the blue channel value of the given encoded color, as a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive.
366         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}
367         * @return a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive, representing the blue channel value of the given encoded color
368         */
369        public static float blue(final float encoded)
370        {
371                final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
372                final float L = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
373                final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
374                final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
375                final float l = cube(L + 0.3963377774f * A + 0.2158037573f * B);
376                final float m = cube(L - 0.1055613458f * A - 0.0638541728f * B);
377                final float s = cube(L - 0.0894841775f * A - 1.2914855480f * B);
378                return reverseGamma(MathUtils.clamp(-0.0041119885f * l - 0.7034763098f * m + 1.7068625689f * s, 0f, 1f));
379        }
380
381        /**
382         * Gets the alpha channel value of the given encoded color, as a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive.
383         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}
384         * @return a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive, representing the alpha channel value of the given encoded color
385         */
386        public static float alpha(final float encoded)
387        {
388                return ((NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encoded) & 0xfe000000) >>> 24) * 0x1.020408p-8f;
389        }
390
391        /**
392         * Gets a color as an Oklab packed float given floats representing hue, saturation, lightness, and opacity.
393         * All parameters should normally be between 0 and 1 inclusive, though any hue is tolerated (precision loss may
394         * affect the color if the hue is too large). A hue of 0 is red, progressively higher hue values go to orange,
395         * yellow, green, blue, and purple before wrapping around to red as it approaches 1. A saturation of 0 is grayscale,
396         * a saturation of 1 is brightly colored, and values close to 1 will usually appear more distinct than values close
397         * to 0, especially if the hue is different. A lightness of 0.001f or less is always black (also using a shortcut if
398         * this is the case, respecting opacity), while a lightness of 1f is white. Very bright colors are mostly in a band
399         * of high-saturation where lightness is 0.5f.
400         *
401         * @param hue        0f to 1f, color wheel position
402         * @param saturation 0f to 1f, 0f is grayscale and 1f is brightly colored
403         * @param lightness  0f to 1f, 0f is black and 1f is white
404         * @param opacity    0f to 1f, 0f is fully transparent and 1f is opaque
405         * @return a float encoding a color with the given properties
406         */
407        public static float floatGetHSL(float hue, float saturation, float lightness, float opacity) {
408                if (lightness <= 0.001f) {
409                        return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat((((int) (opacity * 255f) << 24) & 0xFE000000) | 0x7F7F00);
410                } else {
411                        return fromRGBA(FloatColors.hsl2rgb(hue, saturation, lightness, opacity));
412                }
413        }
414
415        /**
416         * Gets the saturation of the given encoded color, as a float ranging from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive.
417         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}
418         * @return the saturation of the color from 0.0 (a grayscale color; inclusive) to 1.0 (a bright color, inclusive)
419         */
420        public static float saturation(final float encoded) {
421                final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
422                final float L = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
423                if(Math.abs(L - 0.5) > 0.495f) return 0f;
424                final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
425                final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
426                final float l = cube(L + 0.3963377774f * A + 0.2158037573f * B);
427                final float m = cube(L - 0.1055613458f * A - 0.0638541728f * B);
428                final float s = cube(L - 0.0894841775f * A - 1.2914855480f * B);
429                final float r = reverseGamma(MathUtils.clamp(+4.0767245293f * l - 3.3072168827f * m + 0.2307590544f * s, 0f, 1f));
430                final float g = reverseGamma(MathUtils.clamp(-1.2681437731f * l + 2.6093323231f * m - 0.3411344290f * s, 0f, 1f));
431                final float b = reverseGamma(MathUtils.clamp(-0.0041119885f * l - 0.7034763098f * m + 1.7068625689f * s, 0f, 1f));
432                float x, y, w;
433                if(g < b) {
434                        x = b;
435                        y = g;
436                }
437                else {
438                        x = g;
439                        y = b;
440                }
441                if(r < x) {
442                        w = r;
443                }
444                else {
445                        w = x;
446                        x = r;
447                }
448                return x - Math.min(w, y);
449//              float d = x - Math.min(w, y);
450//              float li = x * (1f - 0.5f * d / (x + 1e-10f));
451//              return (x - li); // (Math.min(li, 1f - li) + 1e-10f);
452        }
453
454        public static float lightness(final float encoded) {
455                final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
456                final float L = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
457                final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
458                final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
459                final float l = cube(L + 0.3963377774f * A + 0.2158037573f * B);
460                final float m = cube(L - 0.1055613458f * A - 0.0638541728f * B);
461                final float s = cube(L - 0.0894841775f * A - 1.2914855480f * B);
462                final float r = reverseGamma(MathUtils.clamp(+4.0767245293f * l - 3.3072168827f * m + 0.2307590544f * s, 0f, 1f));
463                final float g = reverseGamma(MathUtils.clamp(-1.2681437731f * l + 2.6093323231f * m - 0.3411344290f * s, 0f, 1f));
464                final float b = reverseGamma(MathUtils.clamp(-0.0041119885f * l - 0.7034763098f * m + 1.7068625689f * s, 0f, 1f));
465                float x, y, w;
466                if(g < b) {
467                        x = b;
468                        y = g;
469                }
470                else {
471                        x = g;
472                        y = b;
473                }
474                if(r < x) {
475                        w = r;
476                }
477                else {
478                        w = x;
479                        x = r;
480                }
481                float d = x - Math.min(w, y);
482                return x * (1f - 0.5f * d / (x + 1e-10f));
483        }
484
485        /**
486         * Gets the hue of the given encoded color, as a float from 0f (inclusive, red and approaching orange if increased)
487         * to 1f (exclusive, red and approaching purple if decreased).
488         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}
489         * @return The hue of the color from 0.0 (red, inclusive) towards orange, then yellow, and
490         * eventually to purple before looping back to almost the same red (1.0, exclusive)
491         */
492        public static float hue(final float encoded) {
493                final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
494                final float L = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
495                final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
496                final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
497                final float l = cube(L + 0.3963377774f * A + 0.2158037573f * B);
498                final float m = cube(L - 0.1055613458f * A - 0.0638541728f * B);
499                final float s = cube(L - 0.0894841775f * A - 1.2914855480f * B);
500                final float r = reverseGamma(MathUtils.clamp(+4.0767245293f * l - 3.3072168827f * m + 0.2307590544f * s, 0f, 1f));
501                final float g = reverseGamma(MathUtils.clamp(-1.2681437731f * l + 2.6093323231f * m - 0.3411344290f * s, 0f, 1f));
502                final float b = reverseGamma(MathUtils.clamp(-0.0041119885f * l - 0.7034763098f * m + 1.7068625689f * s, 0f, 1f));
503                float x, y, z, w;
504                if(g < b) {
505                        x = b;
506                        y = g;
507                        z = -1f;
508                        w = 2f / 3f;
509                }
510                else {
511                        x = g;
512                        y = b;
513                        z = 0f;
514                        w = -1f / 3f;
515                }
516                if(r < x) {
517                        z = w;
518                        w = r;
519                }
520                else {
521                        w = x;
522                        x = r;
523                }
524                float d = x - Math.min(w, y);
525                return Math.abs(z + (w - y) / (6f * d + 1e-10f));
526        }
527
528        /**
529         * The "L" channel of the given packed float in Oklab format, which is its lightness; ranges from 0.0f to
530         * 1.0f . You can edit the L of a color with {@link #lighten(float, float)} and {@link #darken(float, float)}.
531         *
532         * @param encoded a color encoded as a packed float, as by {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}
533         * @return the L value as a float from 0.0f to 1.0f
534         */
535        public static float channelL(final float encoded)
536        {
537                return (NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encoded) & 0xff) / 255f;
538        }
539
540        /**
541         * The "A" channel of the given packed float in Oklab format, which when combined with the B channel describes the
542         * hue and saturation of a color; ranges from 0f to 1f . If A is 0f, the color will be cooler, more green or
543         * blue; if A is 1f, the color will be warmer, from magenta to orange. You can edit the A of a color with
544         * {@link #raiseA(float, float)} and {@link #lowerA(float, float)}.
545         * @param encoded a color encoded as a packed float, as by {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}
546         * @return the A value as a float from 0.0f to 1.0f
547         */
548        public static float channelA(final float encoded)
549        {
550                return ((NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encoded) >>> 8 & 0xff)) / 255f;
551        }
552
553        /**
554         * The "B" channel of the given packed float in Oklab format, which when combined with the A channel describes the
555         * hue and saturation of a color; ranges from 0f to 1f . If B is 0f, the color will be more "artificial", more
556         * blue or purple; if B is 1f, the color will be more "natural", from green to yellow to orange. You can edit
557         * the B of a color with {@link #raiseB(float, float)} and {@link #lowerB(float, float)}.
558         * @param encoded a color encoded as a packed float, as by {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}
559         * @return the B value as a float from 0.0f to 1.0f
560         */
561        public static float channelB(final float encoded)
562        {
563                return ((NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encoded) >>> 16 & 0xff)) / 255f;
564        }
565
566        /**
567         * Gets a variation on the packed float color basis as another packed float that has its hue, saturation, value, and
568         * opacity adjusted by the specified amounts. Takes floats representing the amounts of change to apply to hue,
569         * saturation, value, and opacity; these can be between -1f and 1f. Returns a float that can be used as a packed or
570         * encoded color with methods like {@link com.badlogic.gdx.graphics.g2d.Batch#setPackedColor(float)}. The float is
571         * likely to be different than the result of {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)} unless hue, saturation,
572         * value, and opacity are all 0. This won't allocate any objects.
573         * <br>
574         * The parameters this takes all specify additive changes for a color component, clamping the final values so they
575         * can't go above 1 or below 0, with an exception for hue, which can rotate around if lower or higher hues would be
576         * used. As an example, if you give this 0.4f for saturation, and the current color has saturation 0.7f, then the
577         * resulting color will have 1f for saturation. If you gave this -0.1f for saturation and the current color again
578         * has saturation 0.7f, then resulting color will have 0.6f for saturation.
579         *
580         * @param basis      a packed float color that will be used as the starting point to make the next color
581         * @param hue        -1f to 1f, the hue change that can be applied to the new float color (not clamped, wraps)
582         * @param saturation -1f to 1f, the saturation change that can be applied to the new float color
583         * @param value      -1f to 1f, the value/brightness change that can be applied to the new float color
584         * @param opacity    -1f to 1f, the opacity/alpha change that can be applied to the new float color
585         * @return a float encoding a variation of basis with the given changes
586         */
587        public static float toEditedFloat(float basis, float hue, float saturation, float value, float opacity) {
588                final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(basis);
589                final float L = MathUtils.clamp(value + (decoded & 0xff) / 255f, 0f, 1f);
590                opacity = MathUtils.clamp(opacity + (decoded >>> 24 & 0xfe) * 0x1.020408p-8f, 0f, 1f);
591                if (L <= 0.001f)
592                        return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat((((int) (opacity * 255f) << 24) & 0xFE000000) | 0x808000);
593                final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
594                final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
595                final float l = cube(L + 0.3963377774f * A + 0.2158037573f * B);
596                final float m = cube(L - 0.1055613458f * A - 0.0638541728f * B);
597                final float s = cube(L - 0.0894841775f * A - 1.2914855480f * B);
598                final float r = reverseGamma(MathUtils.clamp(+4.0767245293f * l - 3.3072168827f * m + 0.2307590544f * s, 0f, 1f));
599                final float g = reverseGamma(MathUtils.clamp(-1.2681437731f * l + 2.6093323231f * m - 0.3411344290f * s, 0f, 1f));
600                final float b = reverseGamma(MathUtils.clamp(-0.0041119885f * l - 0.7034763098f * m + 1.7068625689f * s, 0f, 1f));
601                float x, y, z, w;
602                if(g < b) {
603                        x = b;
604                        y = g;
605                        z = -1f;
606                        w = 2f / 3f;
607                }
608                else {
609                        x = g;
610                        y = b;
611                        z = 0f;
612                        w = -1f / 3f;
613                }
614                if(r < x) {
615                        z = w;
616                        w = r;
617                }
618                else {
619                        w = x;
620                        x = r;
621                }
622                float d = x - Math.min(w, y);
623                float hue2 = Math.abs(z + (w - y) / (6f * d + 1e-10f));
624                float sat2 = (x - L) / (Math.min(L, 1f - L) + 1e-10f);
625                return fromRGBA(FloatColors.hsl2rgb(hue2 + hue + 1 - (int)(hue2 + hue + 1), MathUtils.clamp(saturation + sat2, 0f, 1f), L, opacity));
626        }
627
628        /**
629         * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards white by change. While change should be between 0f (return
630         * start as-is) and 1f (return white), start should be a packed color, as from
631         * {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary Colors, and
632         * is a little more efficient and clear than using {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp towards
633         * white. Unlike {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)}, this keeps the alpha and both chroma of start as-is.
634         * @see #darken(float, float) the counterpart method that darkens a float color
635         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
636         * @param change how much to go from start toward white, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means closer to white
637         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and white
638         */
639        public static float lighten(final float start, final float change) {
640                final int s = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(start), i = s & 0xFF, other = s & 0xFEFFFF00;
641                return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(((int) (i + (0xFF - i) * change) & 0xFF) | other);
642        }
643
644        /**
645         * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards black by change. While change should be between 0f (return
646         * start as-is) and 1f (return black), start should be a packed color, as from
647         * {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary Colors, and
648         * is a little more efficient and clear than using {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp towards
649         * black. Unlike {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)}, this keeps the alpha and both chroma of start as-is.
650         * @see #lighten(float, float) the counterpart method that lightens a float color
651         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
652         * @param change how much to go from start toward black, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means closer to black
653         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and black
654         */
655        public static float darken(final float start, final float change) {
656                final int s = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(start), i = s & 0xFF, other = s & 0xFEFFFF00;
657                return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(((int) (i * (1f - change)) & 0xFF) | other);
658        }
659
660        /**
661         * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards a warmer color (orange to magenta) by change. While change
662         * should be between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return fully warmed), start should be a packed color, as from
663         * {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary Colors,
664         * and is a little more efficient and clear than using {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to
665         * lerp towards a warmer color. Unlike {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)}, this keeps the
666         * alpha and L of start as-is.
667         * @see #lowerA(float, float) the counterpart method that cools a float color
668         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
669         * @param change how much to warm start, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means a warmer result
670         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and a warmer color
671         */
672        public static float raiseA(final float start, final float change) {
673                final int s = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(start), p = s >>> 8 & 0xFF, other = s & 0xFEFF00FF;
674                return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(((int) (p + (0xFF - p) * change) << 8 & 0xFF00) | other);
675        }
676
677        /**
678         * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards a cooler color (green to blue) by change. While change
679         * should be between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return fully cooled), start should be a packed color, as from
680         * {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary Colors, and
681         * is a little more efficient and clear than using {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp
682         * towards a cooler color. Unlike {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)}, this keeps the alpha and
683         * L of start as-is.
684         * @see #raiseA(float, float) the counterpart method that warms a float color
685         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
686         * @param change how much to cool start, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means a cooler result
687         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and a cooler color
688         */
689        public static float lowerA(final float start, final float change) {
690                final int s = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(start), p = s >>> 8 & 0xFF, other = s & 0xFEFF00FF;
691                return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(((int) (p * (1f - change)) & 0xFF) << 8 | other);
692        }
693
694        /**
695         * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards a "natural" color (between green and orange) by change.
696         * While change should be between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return fully natural), start should be a packed color, as
697         * from {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary
698         * Colors, and is a little more efficient and clear than using
699         * {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp towards a more natural color. Unlike
700         * {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)}, this keeps the alpha and L of start as-is.
701         * @see #lowerB(float, float) the counterpart method that makes a float color less natural
702         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
703         * @param change how much to change start to a natural color, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means a more natural result
704         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and a more natural color
705         */
706        public static float raiseB(final float start, final float change) {
707                final int s = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(start), t = s >>> 16 & 0xFF, other = s & 0xFE00FFFF;
708                return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(((int) (t + (0xFF - t) * change) << 16 & 0xFF0000) | other);
709        }
710
711        /**
712         * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards an "artificial" color (between blue and purple) by change.
713         * While change should be between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return fully artificial), start should be a packed color, as
714         * from {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary
715         * Colors, and is a little more efficient and clear than using {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp
716         * towards a more artificial color. Unlike {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)}, this keeps the
717         * alpha and L of start as-is.
718         * @see #raiseB(float, float) the counterpart method that makes a float color less artificial
719         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
720         * @param change how much to change start to a bolder color, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means a more artificial result
721         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and a more artificial color
722         */
723        public static float lowerB(final float start, final float change) {
724                final int s = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(start), t = s >>> 16 & 0xFF, other = s & 0xFE00FFFF;
725                return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(((int) (t * (1f - change)) & 0xFF) << 16 | other);
726        }
727
728        /**
729         * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards that color made opaque by change. While change should be
730         * between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return start with full alpha), start should be a packed color, as from
731         * {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary Colors, and
732         * is a little more efficient and clear than using {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp towards
733         * transparent. This won't change the L, A, or B of the color.
734         * @see #fade(float, float) the counterpart method that makes a float color more translucent
735         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
736         * @param change how much to go from start toward opaque, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means closer to opaque
737         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and its opaque version
738         */
739        public static float blot(final float start, final float change) {
740                final int s = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(start), opacity = s >>> 24 & 0xFE, other = s & 0x00FFFFFF;
741                return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(((int) (opacity + (0xFE - opacity) * change) & 0xFE) << 24 | other);
742        }
743
744        /**
745         * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards transparent by change. While change should be between 0
746         * (return start as-is) and 1f (return the color with 0 alpha), start should be a packed color, as from
747         * {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary Colors,
748         * and is a little more efficient and clear than using {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp towards
749         * transparent. This won't change the L, A, or B of the color.
750         * @see #blot(float, float) the counterpart method that makes a float color more opaque
751         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
752         * @param change how much to go from start toward transparent, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means closer to transparent
753         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and transparent
754         */
755        public static float fade(final float start, final float change) {
756                final int s = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(start), opacity = s & 0xFE, other = s & 0x00FFFFFF;
757                return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(((int) (opacity * (1f - change)) & 0xFE) << 24 | other);
758        }
759
760        /**
761         * Brings the chromatic components of {@code start} closer to grayscale by {@code change} (desaturating them). While
762         * change should be between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return fully gray), start should be a packed color, as
763         * from {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}. This only changes A and B; it leaves L and alpha alone, unlike
764         * {@link #lessenChange(float, float)}, which usually changes L.
765         * @see #enrich(float, float) the counterpart method that makes a float color more saturated
766         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
767         * @param change how much to change start to a desaturated color, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means a less saturated result
768         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and a desaturated color
769         */
770        public static float dullen(final float start, final float change) {
771                final int s = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(start);
772                return oklab((s & 0xFF) / 255f,
773                                ((s >>> 8 & 0xFF) / 255f - 0.5f) * (1f - change) + 0.5f,
774                                ((s >>> 16 & 0xFF) / 255f - 0.5f) * (1f - change) + 0.5f,
775                                (s >>> 25) / 127f);
776        }
777
778        /**
779         * Pushes the chromatic components of {@code start} away from grayscale by change (saturating them). While change
780         * should be between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return maximally saturated), start should be a packed color, as
781         * from {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}. This usually changes only A and B, but higher values for
782         * {@code change} can force the color out of the gamut, which this corrects using
783         * {@link #limitToGamut(float, float, float, float)} (and that can change L somewhat). If the color stays in-gamut,
784         * then L won't change; alpha never changes.
785         * @see #dullen(float, float) the counterpart method that makes a float color less saturated
786         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
787         * @param change how much to change start to a saturated color, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means a more saturated result
788         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and a saturated color
789         */
790        public static float enrich(final float start, final float change) {
791                final int s = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(start);
792                return limitToGamut((s & 0xFF) / 255f,
793                                ((s >>> 8 & 0xFF) / 255f - 0.5f) * (1f + change) + 0.5f,
794                                ((s >>> 16 & 0xFF) / 255f - 0.5f) * (1f + change) + 0.5f,
795                                (s >>> 25) / 127f);
796        }
797
798
799        /**
800         * Given a packed float Oklab color {@code mainColor} and another Oklab color that it should be made to contrast with,
801         * gets a packed float Oklab color with roughly inverted L but the same chromatic channels and opacity (A and B
802         * are likely to be clamped if the result gets close to white or black). This won't ever produce black or other very
803         * dark colors, and also has a gap in the range it produces for L values between 0.5 and 0.55. That allows
804         * most of the colors this method produces to contrast well as a foreground when displayed on a background of
805         * {@code contrastingColor}, or vice versa. This will leave the L unchanged if the chromatic channels of the
806         * contrastingColor and those of the mainColor are already very different. This has nothing to do with the contrast
807         * channel of the tweak in ColorfulBatch; where that part of the tweak can make too-similar lightness values further
808         * apart by just a little, this makes a modification on {@code mainColor} to maximize its lightness difference from
809         * {@code contrastingColor} without losing its other qualities.
810         * @param mainColor a packed float color, as produced by {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)};
811         *                     this is the color that will be adjusted
812         * @param contrastingColor a packed float color, as produced by {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)};
813         *                            the adjusted mainColor will contrast with this
814         * @return a different Oklab packed float color, based on mainColor but with potentially very different lightness
815         */
816        public static float inverseLightness(final float mainColor, final float contrastingColor)
817        {
818                final int bits = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(mainColor),
819                                contrastBits = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(contrastingColor),
820                                L = (bits & 0xff),
821                                A = (bits >>> 8 & 0xff),
822                                B = (bits >>> 16 & 0xff),
823                                cL = (contrastBits & 0xff),
824                                cA = (contrastBits >>> 8 & 0xff),
825                                cB = (contrastBits >>> 16 & 0xff);
826                if((A - cA) * (A - cA) + (B - cB) * (B - cB) >= 0x10000)
827                        return mainColor;
828                return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat((bits & 0xFEFFFF00) | (int) (cL < 128 ? L * 0.45f + 140 : 127 - L * 0.45f));
829        }
830
831        /**
832         * Makes the additive Oklab color stored in {@code color} cause less of a change when used as a tint, as if it were
833         * mixed with neutral gray. When {@code fraction} is 1.0, this returns color unchanged; when fraction is 0.0, it
834         * returns {@link Palette#GRAY}, and when it is in-between 0.0 and 1.0 it returns something between the two. This is
835         * meant for things like area of effect abilities that make smaller color changes toward their periphery.
836         * @param color a color that should have its tinting effect potentially weakened
837         * @param fraction how much of {@code color} should be kept, from 0.0 to 1.0
838         * @return an Oklab float color between gray and {@code color}
839         */
840        public static float lessenChange(final float color, float fraction) {
841                final int e = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(color),
842                                sL = 0x80, sA = 0x80, sB = 0x80, sAlpha = 0xFE,
843                                eL = (e & 0xFF), eA = (e >>> 8) & 0xFF, eB = (e >>> 16) & 0xFF, eAlpha = e >>> 24 & 0xFE;
844                return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(((int) (sL + fraction * (eL - sL)) & 0xFF)
845                                | (((int) (sA + fraction * (eA - sA)) & 0xFF) << 8)
846                                | (((int) (sB + fraction * (eB - sB)) & 0xFF) << 16)
847                                | (((int) (sAlpha + fraction * (eAlpha - sAlpha)) & 0xFE) << 24));
848        }
849
850        /**
851         * Makes a quasi-randomly-edited variant on the given {@code color}, allowing typically a small amount of
852         * {@code variance} (such as 0.05 to 0.25) between the given color and what this can return. The {@code seed} should
853         * be different each time this is called, and can be obtained from a random number generator to make the colors more
854         * random, or can be incremented on each call. If the seed is only incremented or decremented, then this shouldn't
855         * produce two similar colors in a row unless variance is very small. The variance affects the L, A, and B of the
856         * generated color, and each of those channels can go up or down by the given variance as long as the total distance
857         * isn't greater than the variance (this considers A and B extra-wide, going from -1 to 1, while L goes from 0 to 1,
858         * but only internally for measuring distance).
859         * @param color a packed float color, as produced by {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}
860         * @param seed a long seed that should be different on each call; should not be 0
861         * @param variance max amount of difference between the given color and the generated color; always less than 1
862         * @return a generated packed float color that should be at least somewhat different from {@code color}
863         */
864        public static float randomEdit(final float color, long seed, final float variance) {
865                final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(color);
866                final float L = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
867                final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
868                final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
869                final float limit = variance * variance;
870                float dist, x, y, z;
871                for (int j = 0; j < 50; j++) {
872                        x = (((seed * 0xD1B54A32D192ED03L >>> 41) - 0x7FFFFFp-1f) * 0x1p-22f) * variance;
873                        y = (((seed * 0xABC98388FB8FAC03L >>> 41) - 0x7FFFFFp-1f) * 0x1p-22f) * variance;
874                        z = (((seed * 0x8CB92BA72F3D8DD7L >>> 41) - 0x7FFFFFp-1f) * 0x1p-22f) * variance;
875                        seed += 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L;
876                        dist = x * x + y * y + z * z;
877                        if(dist <= limit && inGamut(x += L, y = (A + y) * 0.5f + 0.5f, z = (B + z) * 0.5f + 0.5f))
878                                return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat((decoded & 0xFE000000) | ((int)(z * 255.5f) << 16 & 0xFF0000)
879                                        | ((int)(y * 255.5f) << 8 & 0xFF00) | (int)(x * 255.5f));
880                }
881                return color;
882        }
883
884        /**
885         * Returns true if the given packed float color, as Oklab, is valid to convert losslessly back to RGBA.
886         * @param packed a packed float color as Oklab
887         * @return true if the given packed float color can be converted back and forth to RGBA
888         */
889        public static boolean inGamut(final float packed)
890        {
891                final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(packed);
892                final float L = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
893                final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
894                final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
895                final float l = cube(L + 0.3963377774f * A + 0.2158037573f * B);
896                final float m = cube(L - 0.1055613458f * A - 0.0638541728f * B);
897                final float s = cube(L - 0.0894841775f * A - 1.2914855480f * B);
898
899                final float r = +4.0767245293f * l - 3.3072168827f * m + 0.2307590544f * s;
900                if(r < 0f || r > 1.0f) return false;
901                final float g = -1.2681437731f * l + 2.6093323231f * m - 0.3411344290f * s;
902                if(g < 0f || g > 1.0f) return false;
903                final float b = -0.0041119885f * l - 0.7034763098f * m + 1.7068625689f * s;
904                return (b >= 0f && b <= 1.0f);
905        }
906        /**
907         * Returns true if the given Oklab values are valid to convert losslessly back to RGBA.
908         * @param L lightness channel, as a float from 0 to 1
909         * @param A green-to-red chromatic channel, as a float from 0 to 1
910         * @param B blue-to-yellow chromatic channel, as a float from 0 to 1
911         * @return true if the given packed float color can be converted back and forth to RGBA
912         */
913        public static boolean inGamut(float L, float A, float B)
914        {
915                A = (A - 0.5f) * 2f;
916                B = (B - 0.5f) * 2f;
917                final float l = cube(L + 0.3963377774f * A + 0.2158037573f * B);
918                final float m = cube(L - 0.1055613458f * A - 0.0638541728f * B);
919                final float s = cube(L - 0.0894841775f * A - 1.2914855480f * B);
920
921                final float r = +4.0767245293f * l - 3.3072168827f * m + 0.2307590544f * s;
922//              if(r < 0f || r > 1.0f) {
923//                      System.out.println("r out of gamut: " + r);
924//                      return false;
925//              }
926                if(r < 0f || r > 1.0f) return false;
927                final float g = -1.2681437731f * l + 2.6093323231f * m - 0.3411344290f * s;
928//              if(g < 0f || g > 1.0f) {
929//                      System.out.println("g out of gamut: " + g);
930//                      return false;
931//              }
932                if(g < 0f || g > 1.0f) return false;
933                final float b = -0.0041119885f * l - 0.7034763098f * m + 1.7068625689f * s;
934//              if(b < 0f || b > 1.0f) {
935//                      System.out.println("b out of gamut: " + b);
936//                      return false;
937//              }
938//              return true;
939                return (b >= 0f && b <= 1.0f);
940        }
941
942        /**
943         * Iteratively checks whether the given Oklab color is in-gamut, and either brings the color closer to 50% gray if it
944         * isn't in-gamut, or returns it as soon as it is in-gamut.
945         * @param packed a packed float color in Oklab format; often this color is not in-gamut
946         * @return the first color this finds that is between the given Oklab color and 50% gray, and is in-gamut
947         * @see #inGamut(float) You can use inGamut() if you just want to check whether a color is in-gamut.
948         */
949        public static float limitToGamut(final float packed) {
950                final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(packed);
951                final float L = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
952                final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
953                final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
954                float L2 = L, A2 = A, B2 = B;
955                for (int attempt = 31; attempt >= 0; attempt--) {
956                        final float l = cube(L2 + 0.3963377774f * A2 + 0.2158037573f * B2);
957                        final float m = cube(L2 - 0.1055613458f * A2 - 0.0638541728f * B2);
958                        final float s = cube(L2 - 0.0894841775f * A2 - 1.2914855480f * B2);
959
960                        final float r = +4.0767245293f * l - 3.3072168827f * m + 0.2307590544f * s;
961                        final float g = -1.2681437731f * l + 2.6093323231f * m - 0.3411344290f * s;
962                        final float b = -0.0041119885f * l - 0.7034763098f * m + 1.7068625689f * s;
963                        if(r >= 0f && r <= 1f && g >= 0f && g <= 1f && b >= 0f && b <= 1f)
964                                break;
965                        final float progress = attempt * 0x1p-5f;
966                        L2 = MathUtils.lerp(0.55f, L, progress); //TODO: Verify what the middle-gray L value is
967                        A2 = MathUtils.lerp(0, A, progress);
968                        B2 = MathUtils.lerp(0, B, progress);
969                }
970                return oklab(L2, A2 * 0.5f + 0.5f, B2 * 0.5f + 0.5f, (decoded >>> 25) / 127f);
971        }
972
973        /**
974         * Iteratively checks whether the given Oklab color is in-gamut, and either brings the color closer to 50% gray if it
975         * isn't in-gamut, or returns it as soon as it is in-gamut. This always produces an opaque color.
976         * @param L lightness component; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
977         * @param A green-to-red chromatic component; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
978         * @param B blue-to-yellow chromatic component; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
979         * @return the first color this finds that is between the given Oklab color and 50% gray, and is in-gamut
980         * @see #inGamut(float, float, float)  You can use inGamut() if you just want to check whether a color is in-gamut.
981         */
982        public static float limitToGamut(float L, float A, float B) {
983                return limitToGamut(L, A, B, 1f);
984        }
985        /**
986         * Iteratively checks whether the given Oklab color is in-gamut, and either brings the color closer to 50% gray if it
987         * isn't in-gamut, or returns it as soon as it is in-gamut.
988         * @param L lightness component; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
989         * @param A green-to-red chromatic component; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
990         * @param B blue-to-yellow chromatic component; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
991         * @param alpha alpha component; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
992         * @return the first color this finds that is between the given Oklab color and 50% gray, and is in-gamut
993         * @see #inGamut(float, float, float)  You can use inGamut() if you just want to check whether a color is in-gamut.
994         */
995        public static float limitToGamut(float L, float A, float B, float alpha) {
996                float L2 = L = MathUtils.clamp(L, 0f, 1f);
997                float A2 = A = MathUtils.clamp((A - 0.5f) * 2f, -1f, 1f);
998                float B2 = B = MathUtils.clamp((B - 0.5f) * 2f, -1f, 1f);
999                alpha = MathUtils.clamp(alpha, 0f, 1f);
1000                for (int attempt = 31; attempt >= 0; attempt--) {
1001                        final float l = cube(L2 + 0.3963377774f * A2 + 0.2158037573f * B2);
1002                        final float m = cube(L2 - 0.1055613458f * A2 - 0.0638541728f * B2);
1003                        final float s = cube(L2 - 0.0894841775f * A2 - 1.2914855480f * B2);
1004
1005                        final float r = +4.0767245293f * l - 3.3072168827f * m + 0.2307590544f * s;
1006                        final float g = -1.2681437731f * l + 2.6093323231f * m - 0.3411344290f * s;
1007                        final float b = -0.0041119885f * l - 0.7034763098f * m + 1.7068625689f * s;
1008                        if(r >= 0f && r <= 1f && g >= 0f && g <= 1f && b >= 0f && b <= 1f)
1009                                break;
1010                        final float progress = attempt * 0x1p-5f;
1011                        L2 = MathUtils.lerp(0.55f, L, progress);
1012                        A2 = MathUtils.lerp(0, A, progress);
1013                        B2 = MathUtils.lerp(0, B, progress);
1014                }
1015                return oklab(L2, A2 * 0.5f + 0.5f, B2 * 0.5f + 0.5f, alpha);
1016        }
1017
1018        /**
1019         * Produces a random packed float color that is always in-gamut (and opaque) and should be uniformly distributed.
1020         * @param random a Random object (preferably a subclass of Random, like {@link com.badlogic.gdx.math.RandomXS128})
1021         * @return a packed float color that is always in-gamut
1022         */
1023        public static float randomColor(Random random) {
1024                float L = random.nextFloat();
1025                float A = random.nextFloat();
1026                float B = random.nextFloat();
1027                while (!inGamut(L, A, B)) {
1028                        L = random.nextFloat();
1029                        A = random.nextFloat();
1030                        B = random.nextFloat();
1031                }
1032                return oklab(L, A, B, 1f);
1033        }
1034}
